required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: CTA101 UCAR-T Cell Injection for Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory CD19+ B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia
clinical_study.official_title: CTA101 UCAR-T Cell Injection for Treatment of Relapsed or Refractory CD19+ B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia

lead_sponsor.agency: Kai Lin Xu; Jun Nian Zheng

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to evaluate the safety and feasibility of CTA101 in treating patients with relapsed or refractory CD19+ B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

detailed_description.textblock: This study is indicated for r/r CD19+ B-ALL, the selection of dose levels and the number of subjects are based on clinical trial of similar foreign product, whose primary objective was to explore the safety, main consideration was dose-related safety.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline up to 28 days after T cell infusion
primary_outcome.description: Adverse events assessed according to NCI-CTCAE v5.0 criteria

secondary_outcome.measure: MRD negative overall response rate (MRD- ORR)
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of MRD negative overall response rate (MRD- ORR) at 3 months of treatment
Assessment of ORR (ORR = CR + CRi ) at Month 6, 12, 18 and 24
Assessment of EFS at Month 6, 12, 18 and 24
Assessment of OS at Month 6, 12, 18 and 24

arm_group.description: Dose escalation follows the accelerated titration and the standard 3+3 dose escalation design. A total of 3 dose levels are set for subjects.

intervention.description: Universal CD19-directed CAR-T cells by a single infusion intravenously will be given in escalating doses.

facility.name: Affiliated hospital of Xuzhou medical college

responsible_party.investigator_full_name: Kai Lin Xu; Jun Nian Zheng
